Award.AwardTitle: Investigation of the Oxidation of Stoichiometric and Carbon-Rich Tungsten Carbide Surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Fuel cells are a cornerstone of future energy systems, and their functionality relies on the presence of a powerful and durable catalyst material. The majority of catalysts used in current fuel cell technology are based on costly noble metal materials. An alternative is the use of tungsten carbide, which is also compatible with novel microbial fuel cells. Unfortunately, carbide performance is hindered by surface oxidation. The current project aims to design carbon-rich, nano-structured carbide surfaces to remedy this critical issue. The investigation combines the synthesis and characterization of a set of novel carbon-rich carbide surfaces, and the observation with surface science analytical methods of the critical chemical reactions with oxygen and water. It is positioned at the intersection between fundamental and applied research, and has the potential to decisively broaden the range of effective catalyst materials.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Transition metal carbide surfaces such as tungsten carbide, are promising substitutes for noble metal catalysts in fuel cells, steam reforming and as a catalyst support. A critical limitation to their use is their susceptibility to oxidation, which modifies and depresses performance. The present study is based on the hypothesis that a carbon-rich, nanostructured carbide surface can be designed, where degradation through oxidation is minimized. A non-stoichiometric tungsten carbide is grown using a method that is closely related to molecular beam epitaxy, and the transformation of the surface during the reaction with water and oxygen is observed with a suite of complementary surface science techniques. This investigation connects surface characteristics to reactivity from the atomic to the mesoscale, and opens the pathway to the design of advanced tungsten carbide catalysts. The research is coupled with an educational component that engages the public and students at all levels. A particular focus is informal science education, which includes the design of a new exhibit, the "Energy Corner", and a strong collaboration with NISE (Nanoscale Informal Science Education, http://www.nisenet.org/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Investigation of the Oxidation of Stoichiometric and Carbon-Rich Tungsten Carbides

Intellectual Merit: Tungsten carbide is a material with a wide range of uses from hard coatings on cutting tools to catalysts and electrode materials in fuel cells. Our research focussed on the surface oxidation of tungsten carbide which is detrimental to its performance. We demonstrated that a self-regenerating carbide surface can be made by using a carbon-rich carbide film thus mitigating the detrimental impact of oxidation on performance. The original carbide surface can be restored partially or completely by using a mild annealing process. The focus of our work was the synthesis of carbon rich carbide thin films with the potential for self healing, and the study of the oxidation-recarburization cycle with nanoscale resolution. The materials and surface reactions were observed using Scanning Tunneling Microscopy (STM) and Spectroscopy (STS), and X-ray photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) in ambient pressure environment, which yields chemical information.

The carbon-rich tungsten carbide thin films are synthesized by co-deposition of C60 molecules and W, which are condensed on an inert MgO substrate at 800 ºC. The reaction leads to fine-grained WC2 where graphene and graphite layers are embedded in the matrix and the carbon inventory is highly controlled. The high reaction temperature is required to break up the C60 cage, which is surprisingly stable. In the course of the thin film study we discovered a new material, which we termed "nanospheres". Nanospheres are formed from C60 molecules, which react (partially) with the W-substrate and their bandgap can be controlled by the annealing temperature. However, their near-spherical shape is retained allowing for independent control of electronic and geometric structure.

The carbon-rich carbide thin films are then exposed to oxygen to mimic environmental oxidation. We observed the oxidation at the nanoscale, and could follow the growth of the oxide layer. The observation of the surface and analysis of large datasets from spectroscopy measurements was done with a custom-made image and data analysis program. We were able to follow the evolution of the oxide and the subsequent recarburization step through several cycles. This experiment shows clearly the successful surface regeneration, and the interface between the graphite sheets and the oxide-and carbide grains plays a critical role in the transition. The details of reaction mechanism are not yet fully understood and are subject to future studies.

Broader Impact: The development of self-regenerating carbide surfaces has implications for a wide range of industrial processes and the advancement of fuel cell technology. This work has the potential to extend far beyond the tungsten carbide thin films we used in the present study and transform the way we design carbide electrodes and catalysts. Throughout the project period the PI wrote and published a book "Inorganic Nanostructures" with Wiley-VCH, which was based on an undergraduate course in Nanoscience and -technology developed by the PI. In addition, we were actively contributed to numerous outreach events such as NanoDays, and specifically, events targeted at the recruiting of a diverse student body in collaboration with the Center for Diversity at UVa's engineering school.
